info.game_comments:
Justin Sausville game 3.
First game of Season 28.
New title graphics.
First show closed captioning sponsor message aired at end of second break rather than before Final Jeopardy!
Alex limps onstage wearing a boot for his Achilles' tendon injury, and conducts contestant interviews from behind his own host's lectern.

(1, 1).clue: "I indeed baptize you with water; but one mightier than I cometh"

(3, 1).clue: Setting sail for the Paris Peace Conference in December 1918, he became the first sitting president to cross the Atlantic

(4, 1).clue: In September 1984 "Jeopardy!" began its run & P.W. Botha began a more modest 6 years as pres. of this country

(5, 1).clue: Chapter 7 of this federal code provides for liquidation

(6, 1).clue: Tim McGraw & Faith Hill spearheaded the 2010 concert called this Tennessee city "Rising", a benefit for flood victims

(1, 2).clue: "Ye shall not surely die... ye shall be as gods, knowing good and evil"

(3, 2).clue: In 1855, when he was 21, he moved to Paris to study art; that painting of his mother would come later

(4, 2).clue: This literary character spent 28 years marooned on a desert island

(5, 2).clue: In a theater, the mezzanine is the lowest one

(6, 2).clue: Annie Lennox joined David Bowie & the surviving members of Queen on "Under Pressure" at a 1992 AIDS benefit & tribute to this man

(1, 3).clue: "Art thou the king of the Jews?"

(3, 3).clue: Familiar with France from experimenting there, in 1779 he became our first ambassador to France

(4, 3).clue: The Z28 Camaro is a classic muscle car from this automaker

(5, 3).clue: All hail the grain of this plant, used in making beer

(6, 3).clue: The Rolling Stones brought their pals to this Canadian city for a 2003 benefit to help it recover from a SARS outbreak

(1, 4).clue: "Ye shall return unto the land of your possession, and enjoy it, which Moses... gave you on this side Jordan"

(3, 4).clue: He was studying at the Sorbonne in Paris when he published "The Naked and the Dead"

(4, 4).clue: Seen here is one of the 28 hurdles that are part of this track event

(5, 4).clue: The temperature is so mild & pleasant, it's downright this 5-letter adjective

(6, 4).clue: "My friend... told me that he wanted help before" this country "died", George Harrison sang in 1971; he had a benefit for it

(1, 5).clue: "Hail, thou that art highly favoured, the Lord is with thee: blessed art thou among women"

(3, 5).clue: Sadly, this dancer's 2 children drowned in the Seine years before that scarf cut her own life short

(4, 5).clue: This great king succeeded his brother Ethelred in 871 & reigned in Wessex for 28 years

(5, 5).clue: A tongue twister mentions rubber bumpers on this 2-word conveyance (both words fit the category)

(6, 5).clue: Many rockin' friends have joined this guy with a heart of gold at his annual Bridge School Benefit

(2, 1).clue: The origin of "smart as" this referred to the pain caused by its lash

(3, 1).clue: When a pilot dives & rolls & then pulls out in the opposite direction, the maneuver is called the split-this letter

(4, 1).clue: Revealed in "Goldmember", the real name of this twin is Dougie Powers

(5, 1).clue: He's the first labor leader & the first Hispanic American to be honored with a public legal holiday

(6, 1).clue: Steve is a big fan of this federal insurance program that began covering those over 65 back in '65

(2, 2).clue: This phrase meaning "to admit defeat" comes from boxing, where a trainer does it to stop the fight

(3, 2).clue: In 1950 a U.S. F-80 shot down a Soviet-made MiG-15 in the first dogfight between 2 aircraft propelled by this engine

(4, 2).clue: Under this 1997 title alias, FBI agent Johnny Depp infiltrates the mob

(5, 2).clue: In 1982 Richard Cavazos became the first Hispanic American with this many stars as a full general in the army

(6, 2).clue: Eric could use a new health plan; he's got a $50,000 this, the amount he pays out of pocket before insurance kicks in

(2, 3).clue: A Thomas Gray poem says, "Where" this "is bliss, 'tis folly to be wise"

(3, 3).clue: In an early dogfight, British ace Lanoe Hawker was outdueled & killed by this notorious German

(4, 3).clue: Prior to volunteering for experimental research, he was Steve Rogers; now we know him as this

(5, 3).clue: In 1973 this late Pittsburgh Pirate became the first Hispanic American inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame

(6, 3).clue: Jennifer loves this as a type of trim on her clothes & as a type of benefit, like her free company gym

(2, 4).clue: This 2-word term for first prize comes from what serves as the badge of Britain's Order of the Garter

(3, 4).clue: WWI ace Oswald Boelcke advised attacking pilots to keep this behind them so as to interfere with an enemy's vision

(4, 4).clue: Matt Damon as this title character murders Dickie Greenleaf & assumes his identity

(5, 4).clue: This onetime husband of Rosemary Clooney was the first Hispanic American to win the Oscar for Best Actor

(6, 4).clue: Matt's employer lets him choose among various benefits; it's this type of plan, like his favorite eating spot

(2, 5).clue: This type of victory in which the losses are ruinous is named for a cousin of Alexander the Great

(3, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew presents the clue on a monitor.)  The blue pilot sees the red plane at a position called 12 o'clock; after a tight overhead loop to attack, the red plane is now directly behind in the position called this time of day

(4, 5).clue: In "The Usual Suspects", Verbal Kint might have been this killer

(5, 5).clue: In the 1990s he was the first Hispanic Secretary of Transportation & Secretary of Energy

(6, 5).clue: Shh, don't tell!  Suzanne used her medical FSA, short for this, to pay for botox treatments

(0, 0).clue: In the 1840s he wrote, "I ask for, not at once no government, but at once a better government"
